issue.title: Fix bug in mapping
issue.body:
The regexp wouldn't catch when the `closer#close` function was directly mapped to, leading to chains of the mapping similar to this:

```
closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(...)))))
```

and the output of `<CR>` being very messy.

comment.body: This works for me. I'd stopped using vim-closer because of this issue.

issue.title: Zoom modal scratch window causes PaperWM, gnome-shell crash (libmutter involved?)
issue.body:
Running into this issue after a Zoom call ends with the "Host has ended the meeting" modal. When the post-call Zoom modal opens, I get a crash that seems to cause PaperWM to crash and restart.

## Steps to reproduce

- Start a Zoom call on another device
- Join the Zoom call from the device running PaperWM
- Terminate the Zoom call from the other device

## Expected behavior

The "Host has ended the meeting" modal appears, and PaperWM does not crash

## Actual behavior

When the "Host has ended the meeting" modal appears, it has no window controls. PaperWM seems to crash and restart soon after.

## Error messages from `journalctl $(which gnome-shell)`

```

issue.title: ENVELOPE datetime is not aware
issue.body:
```
DEBUG:imapclient.imaplib:< b'* 1 FETCH (UID 27718 ENVELOPE ("Mon, 14 Mar 2022 04:26:15 +0000" "Folder shared with you==REDACTED=="" (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "gmail.com")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")(NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) NIL "<==REDACTED==@docs-share.google.com>" "<==REDACTED==@google.com>"))'
```

Example from a real email from Google.
This generates a naive datetime object `datetime.datetime(2022, 3, 13, 21, 26, 15)` The datetime object in the envelope instance should be aware because the IMAP server returns the time with timezone offset (UTC).

issue.title: ENVELOPE datetime is not aware
issue.body:
```
DEBUG:imapclient.imaplib:< b'* 1 FETCH (UID 27718 ENVELOPE ("Mon, 14 Mar 2022 04:26:15 +0000" "Folder shared with you==REDACTED=="" (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "gmail.com")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")(NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) NIL "<==REDACTED==@docs-share.google.com>" "<==REDACTED==@google.com>"))'
```

Example from a real email from Google.
This generates a naive datetime object `datetime.datetime(2022, 3, 13, 21, 26, 15)` The datetime object in the envelope instance should be aware because the IMAP server returns the time with timezone offset (UTC).

comment.body:
IMAPClient instances have a `normalise_times` attribute which can be used to control whether times are returned as timezone naive in local time or with tz information attached. Set it to false if you want timezone aware datetimes.

https://imapclient.readthedocs.io/en/master/api.html#imapclient.IMAPClient

issue.title: how to search and fetch with some specific criteria?
issue.body:
I follow the docs on [https://imapclient.readthedocs.io/en/2.3.1/](url) to custom search and fetch but it doesn't turn out to be good.

for example, 
i tried to search a certain email with 
```python
mclient.search(['TO', 'xxxx'])
```
but encountered with "InvalidCriteriaError"

and then I tried
```python
mclient.search(['HEADER','TO','xxxx'])
```
no error, but the response is null


then, I tried to fetch the header information,
```python
mclient.fetch(249, data= ['BODY[HEADER.FIELDS (to)]'])[249]
```
it worked with 'to' info returned

```python
mclient.fetch(249, data= ['BODY[HEADER.FIELDS (X-FFF)]'])[249]
```
X-FFF is a customised header field, the response is null

comment.body: Which server are you talking to? Your first attempt looks correct.

payload.description: My personal config files, managed by yadm
My personal config files, managed by yadm

commits.message:
chore: convert from `optparse` to `argparse`

The `optparse` library has been deprecated since Python 3.2 [1]

Convert `optparse` usage to the `argparse` library.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/optparse.html

issue.title: Fix bug in mapping
issue.body:
The regexp wouldn't catch when the `closer#close` function was directly mapped to, leading to chains of the mapping similar to this:

```
closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(...)))))
```

and the output of `<CR>` being very messy.

comment.body: This works for me. I'd stopped using vim-closer because of this issue.

issue.title: Zoom modal scratch window causes PaperWM, gnome-shell crash (libmutter involved?)
issue.body:
Running into this issue after a Zoom call ends with the "Host has ended the meeting" modal. When the post-call Zoom modal opens, I get a crash that seems to cause PaperWM to crash and restart.

## Steps to reproduce

- Start a Zoom call on another device
- Join the Zoom call from the device running PaperWM
- Terminate the Zoom call from the other device

## Expected behavior

The "Host has ended the meeting" modal appears, and PaperWM does not crash

## Actual behavior

When the "Host has ended the meeting" modal appears, it has no window controls. PaperWM seems to crash and restart soon after.

## Error messages from `journalctl $(which gnome-shell)`

issue.title: ENVELOPE datetime is not aware
issue.body:
```
DEBUG:imapclient.imaplib:< b'* 1 FETCH (UID 27718 ENVELOPE ("Mon, 14 Mar 2022 04:26:15 +0000" "Folder shared with you==REDACTED=="" (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "gmail.com")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")(NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) NIL "<==REDACTED==@docs-share.google.com>" "<==REDACTED==@google.com>"))'
```

Example from a real email from Google.
This generates a naive datetime object `datetime.datetime(2022, 3, 13, 21, 26, 15)` The datetime object in the envelope instance should be aware because the IMAP server returns the time with timezone offset (UTC).

issue.title: ENVELOPE datetime is not aware
issue.body:
```
DEBUG:imapclient.imaplib:< b'* 1 FETCH (UID 27718 ENVELOPE ("Mon, 14 Mar 2022 04:26:15 +0000" "Folder shared with you==REDACTED=="" (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "gmail.com")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")(NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) NIL "<==REDACTED==@docs-share.google.com>" "<==REDACTED==@google.com>"))'
```

Example from a real email from Google.
This generates a naive datetime object `datetime.datetime(2022, 3, 13, 21, 26, 15)` The datetime object in the envelope instance should be aware because the IMAP server returns the time with timezone offset (UTC).

comment.body:
IMAPClient instances have a `normalise_times` attribute which can be used to control whether times are returned as timezone naive in local time or with tz information attached. Set it to false if you want timezone aware datetimes.

https://imapclient.readthedocs.io/en/master/api.html#imapclient.IMAPClient

issue.title: how to search and fetch with some specific criteria?
issue.body:
I follow the docs on [https://imapclient.readthedocs.io/en/2.3.1/](url) to custom search and fetch but it doesn't turn out to be good.

for example, 
i tried to search a certain email with 
```python
mclient.search(['TO', 'xxxx'])
```
but encountered with "InvalidCriteriaError"

and then I tried
```python
mclient.search(['HEADER','TO','xxxx'])
```
no error, but the response is null


then, I tried to fetch the header information,
```python
mclient.fetch(249, data= ['BODY[HEADER.FIELDS (to)]'])[249]
```
it worked with 'to' info returned

```python
mclient.fetch(249, data= ['BODY[HEADER.FIELDS (X-FFF)]'])[249]
```
X-FFF is a customised header field, the response is null

comment.body: Which server are you talking to? Your first attempt looks correct.

issue.title: Fix bug in mapping
issue.body:
The regexp wouldn't catch when the `closer#close` function was directly mapped to, leading to chains of the mapping similar to this:

```
closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(closer#close(...)))))
```

and the output of `<CR>` being very messy.

comment.body: This works for me. I'd stopped using vim-closer because of this issue.

issue.title: Zoom modal scratch window causes PaperWM, gnome-shell crash (libmutter involved?)
issue.body:
Running into this issue after a Zoom call ends with the "Host has ended the meeting" modal. When the post-call Zoom modal opens, I get a crash that seems to cause PaperWM to crash and restart.

## Steps to reproduce

- Start a Zoom call on another device
- Join the Zoom call from the device running PaperWM
- Terminate the Zoom call from the other device

## Expected behavior

The "Host has ended the meeting" modal appears, and PaperWM does not crash

## Actual behavior

When the "Host has ended the meeting" modal appears, it has no window controls. PaperWM seems to crash and restart soon after.

## Error messages from `journalctl $(which gnome-shell)`

issue.title: ENVELOPE datetime is not aware
issue.body:
```
DEBUG:imapclient.imaplib:< b'* 1 FETCH (UID 27718 ENVELOPE ("Mon, 14 Mar 2022 04:26:15 +0000" "Folder shared with you==REDACTED=="" (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "gmail.com")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")(NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) NIL "<==REDACTED==@docs-share.google.com>" "<==REDACTED==@google.com>"))'
```

Example from a real email from Google.
This generates a naive datetime object `datetime.datetime(2022, 3, 13, 21, 26, 15)` The datetime object in the envelope instance should be aware because the IMAP server returns the time with timezone offset (UTC).

issue.title: ENVELOPE datetime is not aware
issue.body:
```
DEBUG:imapclient.imaplib:< b'* 1 FETCH (UID 27718 ENVELOPE ("Mon, 14 Mar 2022 04:26:15 +0000" "Folder shared with you==REDACTED=="" (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "drive-shares-dm-noreply" "google.com")) (("==REDACTED==" NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "gmail.com")) ((NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")(NIL NIL "==REDACTED==" "==REDACTED==")) NIL "<==REDACTED==@docs-share.google.com>" "<==REDACTED==@google.com>"))'
```

Example from a real email from Google.
This generates a naive datetime object `datetime.datetime(2022, 3, 13, 21, 26, 15)` The datetime object in the envelope instance should be aware because the IMAP server returns the time with timezone offset (UTC).

comment.body:
IMAPClient instances have a `normalise_times` attribute which can be used to control whether times are returned as timezone naive in local time or with tz information attached. Set it to false if you want timezone aware datetimes.

https://imapclient.readthedocs.io/en/master/api.html#imapclient.IMAPClient

issue.title: how to search and fetch with some specific criteria?
issue.body:
I follow the docs on [https://imapclient.readthedocs.io/en/2.3.1/](url) to custom search and fetch but it doesn't turn out to be good.

for example, 
i tried to search a certain email with 
```python
mclient.search(['TO', 'xxxx'])
```
but encountered with "InvalidCriteriaError"

and then I tried
```python
mclient.search(['HEADER','TO','xxxx'])
```
no error, but the response is null


then, I tried to fetch the header information,
```python
mclient.fetch(249, data= ['BODY[HEADER.FIELDS (to)]'])[249]
```
it worked with 'to' info returned

```python
mclient.fetch(249, data= ['BODY[HEADER.FIELDS (X-FFF)]'])[249]
```
X-FFF is a customised header field, the response is null

comment.body: Which server are you talking to? Your first attempt looks correct.
